fields.value: Political Sophistication and the Dimensionality of Elite and Mass Political Attitudes, 1980-2004

dsDescriptionValue.value: Among the terms central to the literature on political attitudes have been complexity and constraint, with some scholars asserting that increased complexity constrains political attitudes to a single ideological dimension while others argue that complexity instead leads to a multidimensional attitude structure.  We investigate the role of sophistication in structuring issue attitudes using a unique survey of Democratic and Republican party elites in conjunction with the ANES.  The two surveys allow us to compare directly the structure of elite and mass issue attitudes. We hypothesize that elite attitudes are unidimensional and mass attitudes are multidimensional.  The difference, we argue, is that political sophistication constrains elite attitudes to a single ideological dimension, whereas much of the mass public is not fully capable of making the necessary connections between ideology and issue attitudes. The results of comparisons between elite and mass attitude structures from 1980-2004 support our hypotheses.

files.description: Supplemental online appendix providing summary statistics for the political sophistication scale, including for the stratified samples of the mass public, and confirmatory factor analysis results for elites and the mass public, for all years included in the analysis, as well as results from a variety of alternative model specifications.  All analyses presented and described in the supplemental online appendix are mentioned in footnotes throughout the article.
